recommendations: Pique Turn is a movement performed in the passé position while turning to the inside and  usually done in a series.. For practicing Pique Turn as a/an intermediate performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Plie variations: Try doing grand plies in first, second, and fifth positions, as well as demi-plies with various arm positions. , Releves variations: Single-leg, double-legs in first, second and fifth positions, releve passé, Arabesque balances, Spotting exercises: Doing half-turns or full turns with a focus on spotting, Flexibility stretching for 5 repetitions on each side for 10 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Begin with your feet in first position, heels touching and toes pointing outward. Evenly distribute the weight between your feet and core muscles for balance and control., Prepare for the turn by lifting your back foot into a pique position, bringing it to the back of your supporting ankle. Hold this position firmly and securely, and make sure your weight is centered over your supporting foot., Use your supporting leg to initiate the turn by pushing off the ground and lifting your pique foot into a passe position in front of your knee. Keep your core muscles engaged and your arms in a comfortable position for balance and control., As you turn, pivot on your supporting leg and bring your pique foot around to the front, pointing your toes and keeping your leg straight. Keep your eyes focused on a fixed point in front of you to help with spotting, and use your core muscles to help you maintain your balance and control throughout the turn.            , Complete the turn by landing on your supporting leg with your pique foot still in front of your knee. for 5 repetitions on each side for 10 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on artistry, additional exercises could include Flowing port de bras: Work on your port de bras by practicing flowing arm movements, focusing on making smooth transitions and expressive gestures., Dance to different music: Explore different styles of music and try dancing to each one, focusing on expressing the mood and emotion of the music through your movements., Free movement improvisation: Let your body move freely and spontaneously, without any set choreography. Focus on expressing yourself through movement and exploring different levels and dynamics..

Fish Roll and Flop is a movement where the dancer rolls their body in a fluid motion resembling the movement of a fish, while the Flop is a contemporary dance move where the dancer falls to the ground in a sudden and dramatic manner.. For practicing Fish Roll and Flop as a/an advanced performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Yoga dolphin pose: Begin on your hands and knees, then lift your hips up and press your hands and forearms into the ground. Hold for 10-20 seconds, then release., Handstand preparation: Practice handstand preparation exercises, such as kicking up against a wall or using a partner for support., Pilates swan dive: Lie on your stomach with your arms extended in front of you. Lift your arms, chest, and legs off the ground simultaneously, then release back down. Repeat for 10-15 repetitions. for 5 repetitions for 10 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart and engage your core muscles for stability., Lift both shoulders up, then rotate them back, down, and forward in a fluid motion., Increase the speed and fluidity of the movement, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout., Incorporate other upper body movements, such as arm circles, to challenge yourself., Practice regularly to improve your technique and coordination. for 5 repetitions for 10 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on artistry, additional exercises could include Flowing port de bras, Dance to different music, Free movement improvisation.

Axel Turn is a jump in which the skater rotates 360 degrees in the air, landing on the back foot.. For practicing Axel Turn as a/an amateur performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Jumping jacks, Single-leg hops, Tuck jumps for 5 repetitions for 10 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Start in B-plus position., Swing arms forward and jump off back foot., Rotate 360 degrees with legs crossed., Land on the back foot., Practice with a half turn first. for 5 repetitions for 10 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on artistry, additional exercises could include Flowing port de bras, Dance to different music, Free movement improvisation.
